isis.stitle: T 444E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (NAVPAK) (1997) - SECTION 1.6: SENSOR OPERATION - TYPES OF SENSORS - HALL EFFECT SENSOR

svcproc.title: HALL EFFECT SENSOR
svcproc.para: The Hall Effect sensor is an electronic device which generates a voltage. The shape and frequency of this signal depends on how the magnetic field of this sensor is disturbed.

The Camshaft Position sensor is an example of a Hall Effect sensor. It contains a permanent magnet, transducer, signal conditioner and a switching transistor as shown in Figure 1.26.
The sensor's permanent magnet generates a magnetic field around the transducer and the timing sensor disk mounted, to the camshaft gear. As the magnetic field is disturbed by the rotation of the timing disk (vanes and windows) the transducer generates a signal which is filtered and conditioned by the internal CMP sensor signal conditioner.

Once the signal has been conditioned, it is applied to the switching transistor's base which causes the transistor to switch on and ground the 5 volt line from the ECM. At this time, the ECM no longer senses the 5 volt reference signal.
Each time a vane passes no signal is generated by the transducer. This action causes the transistor to shut off and allows the ECM to see it's 5 volt reference signal.

This switching action allows the ECM to determine crankshaft position and engine speed which is required by the ECM to control engine operating parameters such as injector timing, duration (injection pulse width) and Injection Control Pressure.
This sensor is connected to the ECM by three wires: a 5 volt signal supply, a 5 volt power feed for the signal conditioner VDREF and signal ground.
